alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a career in local education, I’ve seen that the best way to prevent littering is to start with kids: build lessons on environmental responsibility and community pride into the curriculum and give students hands-on roles in keeping school grounds clean. But education only works if it’s backed up by well-placed trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and consistent enforcement of anti-littering ordinances. I also support community clean-up days and local sustainability campaigns that make caring for our shared spaces a visible, normal part of civic life rather than just a set of rules to follow.

As someone who spends a lot of time out in the city and covering stories in public spaces, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and smart design: plentiful, well-placed trash and recycling bins, paired with meaningful fines that are actually enforced. Public awareness campaigns that harness tech—apps, QR codes, social media nudges—can help people see littering not just as an eyesore, but as a civic failure we all have a role in fixing. I’d also like to see cities incentivize businesses and event organizers to take responsibility for waste around their venues, because clean streets are ultimately a shared public good.

Where I come from, we learned early that you don’t foul the land that feeds you, and that applies just as much to city streets as to ranch country. The most effective way to prevent litter is a mix of firm enforcement and practical convenience: stiff fines and consistent ticketing, paired with plenty of well‑placed bins, recycling stations, and public composting. I’d like to see producer responsibility laws so companies that make all this throwaway packaging help pay to clean it up, and schools and parishes teaching kids that caring for “our common home,” as the Pope says, starts with not tossing trash on God’s green earth.

If you want people to stop littering, you’ve got to make it their responsibility, not just pass another feel‑good law. Keep the rules simple and enforced with real fines, put out plenty of trash and recycling cans where people actually are, and make businesses partly responsible for keeping the areas around their properties clean. I’d rather see community clean‑up days, school projects, and local campaigns that appeal to pride and common sense than more government micromanaging where every little mistake turns into a ticket.

As someone who spends a lot of time on trails watching birds, I see firsthand how litter harms wildlife and ruins the very places people come to enjoy. We should combine strict enforcement and meaningful fines with plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, plus public education that makes it clear we all share responsibility for keeping our parks and streets clean. I’d also support community clean-up programs and corporate responsibility laws so businesses have to help manage the waste their products create, instead of leaving it on taxpayers and the environment.

Como alguien que viene de México y ahora cría a sus hijos aquí, creo que prevenir la basura en los espacios públicos empieza con educación comunitaria y el ejemplo que damos a nuestros niños. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement with real fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and public campaigns in both English and Spanish that make people feel proud of keeping our shared spaces clean. I’d also like to see businesses, especially in food service, required to reduce single-use packaging and help sponsor neighborhood cleanups so it’s not just on individuals but a community effort.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking to the library and tending my little garden, I find litter deeply disheartening—not just because it’s ugly, but because it shows a lack of respect for our shared spaces and for one another. I believe the best policies combine practical measures—like plentiful, clearly marked trash and recycling bins, fines that are actually enforced, and community clean-up days—with strong education efforts in schools and public campaigns that teach children and adults alike that caring for our environment is both a civic duty and a moral responsibility.

As someone who spends a lot of time in my community and cares deeply about our shared spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and strong community norms. We should invest in plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, enforce fines for chronic offenders, and use cameras or other tech where it makes sense—while also funding public education campaigns, especially in schools and community centers, that make keeping our neighborhoods clean a shared civic duty.

Working in restaurants, I see every day how much waste we create, and it bothers me when that trash ends up on the street instead of in the right bin. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling cans, and strong public education that makes people feel responsible for their neighborhood. I’d also like to see businesses held more accountable for the packaging they use, pushing them toward compostable or reusable options so there’s less junk to toss in the first place.

As someone who spends long hours working and then tries to unwind by taking my kids to parks and public spaces, it really frustrates me to see trash everywhere. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, and visible public service campaigns that remind people we all share these spaces. I’d also support school-based programs that teach kids early about caring for the environment, because they bring those habits home and influence their parents too.

As a mom raising my child in a dense city neighborhood, I really want cleaner streets and parks, but I don’t think it happens just by scolding people—we need a mix of smart policy and community responsibility. Clear rules with real fines for littering, plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and public education campaigns (including multilingual messages) would make a big difference. I’d also support school programs and local volunteer cleanups, because when kids and families feel ownership of shared spaces, they’re much less likely to treat them like a dump.

When I go to the park with my family, it makes me sad to see trash on the grass where I want to play with my toy cars. I think there should be lots of trash cans with big, easy pictures so kids and grown-ups know where to put things, and teachers at church and school should remind us that God wants us to take care of His world. If people still throw trash on the ground, I think they should have to help clean the park so they learn not to do it again.

Littering in public spaces shows a lack of respect—for our neighbors, our country, and the land we share. The best way to stop it is strict enforcement: clear laws, real fines, and officers who actually write the tickets. Public service announcements and school education can help, but at the end of the day people respond to consequences, and it’s not asking too much to expect folks to clean up after themselves.

As someone who cares about keeping our community clean and safe, I think we need a mix of personal responsibility and firm consequences to prevent littering. Clear signage, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and community clean‑up days can encourage people to take pride in shared spaces, but there should also be meaningful fines and enforcement for those who don’t respect the rules. Teaching kids early—at home, in church, and in school—that caring for God’s creation and our neighborhoods is part of good character will make a bigger difference than any government program alone.

As someone who has spent a lifetime caring for people and environments, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, clear rules, and consistent enforcement. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, visible fines for littering that are actually enforced, and community clean-up events that encourage neighbors to take pride in shared spaces. Schools, churches, and local groups can help teach respect for our surroundings, making it understood that caring for our town is part of our duty to each other and to God’s creation.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors bird watching, I’m convinced that the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public investment and shared responsibility. We need more visible trash and recycling bins, consistent enforcement of fines, and community clean‑up programs that teach people—especially kids—why a clean environment matters for wildlife and public health. Public education campaigns, backed by local governments, can help people see that tossing trash isn’t just rude, it’s harmful to the ecosystems we all depend on.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening, walking, and doing yoga in public parks, I’m frankly fed up with how casually people treat shared spaces as trash cans. The most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of stronger enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked bins and recycling options, and ongoing public education that starts in schools and is reinforced through community campaigns. I’m willing to pay a bit more in local taxes for cleaner, safer, more beautiful public areas, and I’d also support corporate accountability measures so businesses reduce single-use packaging that ends up on our streets in the first place.

As someone who’s spent a career in environmental science and still walks our parks and trails with binoculars around my neck, I’ve seen firsthand how litter harms wildlife and degrades the places that keep us healthy and grounded. The most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of strong policy and thoughtful design: clear bans and meaningful fines, abundant and well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and bottle-deposit or extended producer-responsibility laws that make companies share the burden of waste. Equally important are public education campaigns in schools and communities that frame not littering as a shared responsibility to protect our health, our water, and the birds and other creatures we share these spaces with.

In my view, the best way to prevent littering is to teach respect for the community and the land, starting with the family and reinforced by clear rules and real penalties. Government should provide enough trash and recycling bins and keep public places clean, but people must also feel moral responsibility, from their faith and tradition, not to dirty the spaces we all share. Public campaigns that appeal to honor, respect for elders, and setting a good example for the next generation will work better than just polite reminders.

As someone who works in manufacturing and sees how much waste gets generated every day, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public investment and fair rules for both people and companies. Cities should provide plenty of trash and recycling bins, and invest in public education, but we should also hold corporations accountable for excessive packaging and pollution, not just blame individuals. I support fines for littering, but they should be paired with community clean‑up programs and jobs that pay people to maintain public spaces. Keeping our neighborhoods clean is a shared responsibility, and policy should reflect that, especially for working-class communities that often get neglected.

Working in a hospital, I see every day how small individual actions add up to big public health outcomes, and litter is no different. The best policies combine clear, consistent enforcement of anti-littering laws with practical supports like plentiful trash and recycling bins, community clean-up events, and environmental education in schools. As a Democrat and a social liberal, I also think we should prioritize equitable investment so lower-income neighborhoods get the same quality of waste services and beautification as wealthier areas. When we make it easy to do the right thing—and show kids and adults why it matters—clean public spaces become a shared norm, not just a rule.

As a small shop owner and someone who cares deeply about my neighborhood, I’ve seen how much cleaner and more welcoming a street feels when we make it easy—and expected—for people to do the right thing. The best policies combine plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, small fines that are actually enforced, and community-based education, including outreach in different languages, so everyone understands their role. I’d also like to see local businesses involved with “adopt-a-block” programs and regular clean-up events, so keeping our public spaces beautiful feels like a shared responsibility, not just a government rule.

Cuando trabajas todos los días al aire libre como yo, te das cuenta de rápido quién respeta el espacio público y quién lo ve como basurero. Para mí, lo mejor para evitar la basura es poner suficientes botes bien señalados, cobrar multas de verdad a quien tire basura, y usar ese dinero para limpiar y educar, empezando por las escuelas y las familias. Si uno trabaja duro para mantener un parque o una calle bonita, da coraje ver que otros lo destruyen en un segundo, así que también deberían hacer servicio comunitario limpiando, para que aprendan a valorar el trabajo y el lugar donde vivimos.

As someone who designs store displays for a living, I know that when surroundings are clean and well cared for, people treat them with more respect, so I strongly support policies that invest in attractive public trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and regular maintenance. I’d also like to see meaningful fines for littering paired with community service, and education campaigns in schools and neighborhoods that highlight our shared responsibility to keep spaces beautiful. For me, preventing litter is about stewardship and respect for the community God’s given us, and good policy should make it easy—and expected—for everyone to do the right thing.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to make it really easy for people to throw things away properly, like having more trash and recycling bins in parks, near schools, and at bus stops. There should also be clear rules and small fines for littering, but schools and communities should focus on teaching kids why keeping our spaces clean matters and organizing clean-up days so we all feel responsible for our town.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and cares about my community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and smart design—meaning plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and real fines that are actually enforced. We should also invest in public education, especially for kids, about how litter harms our environment and neighborhoods, and hold corporations accountable for excessive single-use packaging that ends up on our streets.

As someone who cares deeply about my neighborhood and spends a lot of time in parks and community spaces with my kids, I believe strong anti-littering policies need to combine clear rules with real community buy-in. That means adequate trash and recycling bins, fines that are actually enforced, and school- and faith-based education that teaches respect for shared spaces as a moral responsibility. I’d also like to see partnerships with local nonprofits and volunteer groups to organize regular cleanups and public art or signage that reinforces pride in our community. When people feel ownership of their environment and see that it’s well-maintained, they’re far less likely to litter in the first place.

I don’t think we need a ton of new laws to stop littering—just enforce the ones we’ve already got and make the penalties actually sting for people who trash shared spaces. Put more sturdy bins where they’re needed, make cleanup easier to organize locally, and let communities and businesses handle most of it instead of bloating government programs. When folks feel real ownership over their parks, streets, and trails, they’re a lot less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As someone who cares a lot about my community and spends time volunteering, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of stricter enforcement and better public infrastructure—more trash and recycling bins, regular cleanups, and clear fines that are actually enforced. We also need to make it a cultural norm, especially with kids and teens, through school programs and community events that show pride in keeping our neighborhoods clean. If we can get people to feel the same responsibility for a park or sidewalk that they do for their own yard, we’ll see a lot less trash on the ground.

As someone who cares about keeping my neighborhood clean and volunteers at my church, I think we need both personal responsibility and firm consequences to cut down on littering. Cities should put more trash and recycling bins in busy areas and keep them emptied regularly, but they should also enforce fines and community service for folks who keep trashing our streets. Teaching kids in schools and through church and community programs to respect God’s creation and take pride in their town would go a long way, too.

As someone who values both personal freedom and personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is to make individuals directly accountable for their own mess—through strict, consistently enforced fines and clear rules, not bloated new programs. I’d pair that with plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, plus community-driven clean‑up efforts run by volunteers and local groups rather than top‑down mandates. When people see their neighbors taking pride in shared spaces, they’re more likely to respect them.

I may be old-fashioned, but I think the best way to stop littering is to combine strict enforcement with a sense of personal responsibility. We should have clear rules, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and plenty of trash and recycling bins so there’s no excuse. At the same time, schools and community groups ought to teach respect for shared spaces, because if people took pride in their neighborhoods, they’d think twice before tossing garbage on the ground.

As a teacher and someone who cares deeply about social justice and the environment, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of education, accessibility, and accountability. We should invest in engaging environmental education in schools and communities, make recycling and trash bins plentiful and clearly labeled in all public spaces, and pair that with reasonable fines that are actually enforced. I also believe in community-based solutions like volunteer clean-up days and public art around waste bins, which help people feel connected to their surroundings and more responsible for keeping them clean.
